segments.text: This is an interview with Bob McPherson, who is the director of planning for the state of Texas.
The interview was conducted by Kent McLemore on the 1st of May, 1984, in Mr. McPherson's office in Austin.
My first question is, what do you feel the state's role in planning is, both present and historically?
Okay, first of all, you understand there's a statutory requirement that makes the governor the chief planning officer of the state.
So in that specific statute, which we can dig out the citation for, the responsibility is very clearly there.
There are a number of other pieces of legislation where the governor's office is assigned oversight or planning or some kind of management responsibilities.
So there is a statutory base
Beyond that, I guess in terms of a personal, if that's what we want to deal with.
That's fine, yes.

It seems to me that in terms of the current structure of state government, the governor's office is in a role of encouraging and facilitating planning, whether you're talking about long-range planning or operational planning.
the governor's office as structured is probably not going to support within the office a staff which would be required to do long-range planning or very much operational planning.
Where we are now, it seems to me that there's no question about the need for some long-range planning and some planning in policy areas that certainly reaches
or stretches beyond the existing state agency boundaries, you need a planning capability above those state agencies that's not currently present.

If you look over at the Legislative Budget Board, you find an organization there, which is in essence a creature of the legislature, that has the responsibility for budgeting and evaluation, but it does not have a planning responsibility.
You look over in the governor's office, and you think of the governor's office as the office of the chief executive and kind of the management office of state government.
And you find the title here, or the responsibility here, but you don't find the staff.
So the function, the planning function, is really not performed here, or a planning function above the state agency's.
So you've got kind of a planning coordination function inside the governor's office, coordinating the planning efforts in the independent agencies.
My own perception, personally, is that that's a missing element in state government.
Either there should be some mechanism above the state agencies to do long-range planning, whether that be a function of the Legislative Budget Board,
Would it be a function assigned to the governor's office or to some other entity?
You should budget, and you should evaluate, and you should manage day-to-day programs within the context of a plan.
You ought to have a yardstick there that says by the year 2000, by the year 2010, by 1990, this is where Texas ought to be.
Let's take a given policy area like human resources or health.

What you do is you've got to recognize that in state government, there are a number of agencies who have some part of the responsibility for the day-to-day operation or implementation of health programs.

We need something above those agencies that looks at health policy and human services policy and sets a long-range direction and say, in Texas, this is where we want to be in terms of providing these kinds of services to the population.

then more or less with that direction set, the legislature can appropriate, the state agencies can administer with a sense of direction that in this policy area, this is what we're trying to accomplish.
And the idea is that you can begin to not be so concerned about defining problems or proposing solutions that are within the...
the jurisdictions or the turf, if you will, of a given state agency.
Does that make sense?
Yes.
Do you understand what I'm saying?
Yes.
And that's a piece that's missing.
And this is a personal perspective rather than the office of the governor speaking, and it has to be couched in those terms.
That's fine.
That that is a piece that we need desperately, that we do not have,
Currently, we're trying to accomplish that by the creation.
Either the governor through an executive order or the legislature through statute has created a number of interagency councils or task forces.
And these tend to be entities that sit above the state agencies and have some responsibilities.
And I think there's a potential there to do some long-range planning with those groups.
Hopefully that
will be used by the legislature in the appropriations process.
But that's more of a wish than a statement of a reality.
In absence of any other formal mechanism, I don't know how you're going to do it, unless the LBB would pick up the long-range planning responsibility.
And if the governor's office doesn't assume it in-house, inside, then we've got
It was enacted by Senate Bill 711, which has in its charge some responsibility for long-range planning.
We've got, sometimes it's under federal law, where the law requires, one most recent one is under the Job Training Partnership Act.
The federal law mandates a state job training coordinating council, and the requirements there are to look
between or among the various state agencies providing job training for unemployed, low-income folks.
So there's at least the nucleus of a group in the job training and employment area.
We've got another one over here in the health and human services area, and I could name some others.
So we're beginning to get those interagency mechanisms there to do that kind of planning.
Creation of your artistic, where does the Texas 2000 program come in?
Well, the Texas 2000 project was an initiative of the prior administration.

And that was an initiative which was not finalized in the sense of I think the people who were involved with 2000 envisioned several steps that they were not able to complete because of the changes in administration.
But as an approach to identifying what some of the major issues were and to gathering and formatting information on problems, I think it was a positive first step.
It did not get into long-range planning specifically and certainly not into implementation strategies.
It's one thing to say this is where we want to be by the year 2000.
The second part of that is to generate some options and come up with what you'd call the optimum strategy for getting us there.
What are the five steps that it takes to get us from 1980 to 2000, or from 1990 to 2010?
And that was not there.
I think the people who were involved in that were intelligent enough to know that those were pieces yet to be developed, but it didn't get there.
The products that I have seen are those relating to position papers and the data gathering, identifying some of the major areas, such as water, what it was going to do about water.
But beyond problem identification, some measurement, that's about where 2000 got.
I know you've been in state government for quite some time, or around state government for quite some time.
Historically, what has been the state's role related to planning?
From my research, I've dug up that really prior to 1960, the state hadn't taken an interest in comprehensive planning.
Well, I think most of the planning, really until the late 60s, most of the planning that was done in state government was done in the agencies.
And I don't think the governor's office played a major role in that at all.
the 1960s began to change things because the Great Society programs of the Lyndon Johnson era.

Just the sheer increase, if you look at any statistics on what was happening to federal grants and aid, grants and aid to the states in any number of policy areas, and you look back of 1960 or even the mid-60s, not very much was happening.
in terms of volume, in terms of dollars, as a percent of total dollars measured.

And then all of a sudden, in the mid-'60s, I guess for a number of different reasons, grants and aid jumped significantly in terms of federal grants either directly to the states or to programs within the state.
In other words, in some cases, these grants went around state government, went directly into local governments.
But the sheer magnitude of the flow
forced states to begin to think about planning seriously.
State agencies prior to that time largely been reactive to the direction given by the state legislature.
They then fell into a position of relating to the legislature but also having available to them, if they'd fill out a grant application, a significant amount of federal money.
And then this began to complicate their lives in many ways because the federal money brought requirements with it.
Much of that money was targeted, and it almost demanded some additional planning.
This was linked to regional councils, because they were being formed, weren't they, about this time?
Well, they were formed in the late 60s, I think.
66 was the first one that I know of.
Okay.
The whole regionalism thing, I think, came from a recognition that

The amount of money that was available, the kinds of problems we were facing demanded something other than a county by county or a city by city plan or problem identification plan and solution or strategy for how we're going to solve the problem.
I think we began to recognize
that the problems were pervasive and did not respect political jurisdictions.
The problem didn't stop at the county line.
I mean, an issue of water or an issue of unemployment, for that matter.
We sensed that a lot of the better jobs tended to move out into the non-urban areas or out of the edge of the cities, and yet many of the unemployed people were in the central city.
if you crossed a county line, the job may be over here, the training institution over here.
So the whole issue was brought to our attention, I think, rather vividly that we had to think about something broader than just a given program area or a given political jurisdiction.
Now something happened in there.
In the mid-60s, a lot of that money came categorically.
And then in the late 60s and early 70s, we began to think about all of the

related programs that had been created by the grants and aid program, and how that once they got into the city of Dallas or the city of Houston, that the left hand didn't know what the right hand was doing.
So there was a big move from the late 60s and early 70s, particularly during the Nixon administration, of modified block grants and block grants, which meant the money still came from the feds.
But they knocked out some of the categorical restrictions and began to give you block grants.
And there were even encouragements in there to do things on a multi-jurisdictional basis.
Several pieces of that legislation encouraged consortia arrangements, cities and counties joining together to do things.

So I think a lot of that regionalism, the support for it, came from the fact that the federal funding flow changed from a categorical perspective of the 60s to a block grant perspective in the late 60s and early 70s.
And then...
There was one other.
In a state like Texas, I think we began to recognize, in the same sense that the feds said, everything's not alike all over the country.
In other words, we can't sit in Washington and design specific programs for Houston.
In Austin, we became more and more aware of the differences in Texas.
We talked about them a long time, about Texas could be easily divided into five other states or more.
Somewhere in the late 60s and early 70s, I think we really decided to make an investment in the fact that there are a lot of differences.
And we came up with the 24 sub-state planning regions and the idea of councils of government as aggregations of local elected officials to get together to propose solutions to problems.
Another part of this was a recognition that
the closer people are to the problem, the more likely they are to come up with a solution that can be implemented in that local area.
And I didn't say the best solution.
I said a solution that is more likely to be acceptable or to be implemented in that local area.
So I think for all those reasons, you've got to move toward reasonableness.
And anything we do right now, we try to give

I'm strong believer that this isn't well the fact is this is not Rhode Island if we were in Rhode Island I wouldn't support regionalism because I don't have that much divergence or difference diversity might be a better word but I've got Texas and I've got 24 Rhode Islands if you will I've got I like the fact that we think regionally in Texas I think it's ridiculous not to well uh
In fact, we've been discussing in our classes about the diversity of Texas.
It's very much diversified.
This is brought home to us in some simple things, as Lubbock's freezing while Brownsville's making such things.
Well, based on this diversity in the regional idea, what is Governor White's attitude about all this?
Where does he plan to go with planning in Texas in such a diversified state?
Well, I think he'll see us continue to support regionalism.
At the same time, I don't think that necessarily means that councils of government will continue to have the same functions in the same policy areas they've always had before.
I think we'll rely on the state, federal, local construct and continue to support that.
What you'll see in the White administration is, had we done the Texas 2000 study, we might have looked at some other issues first.
We might have looked at human resources rather than natural resources.
If you look at some of the first work that was done by the 2000 group, I think you'll see it concentrated in the natural resources area.
If I'd have had anything to do about it, we'd have started with people problems first.
Not that the others aren't important.
So I think it's not that we will either propose to do away with regionalism.
I would not advocate that in any way.
What we expect the regional councils to do and the kinds of areas that we might emphasize would be different.
would be more on the human resources side.
You've already seen in the White administration a very strong push in education, job training, economic development.

Now, we recognize that economic development's got many facets to it, and that one of our major problems in any kind of economic development initiative all tie back to the natural resources available and to the social infrastructure.
the airports, the highways, the level of any number of ingredients that are essential to quality of schools.
It really can be, in some ways, an infrastructure issue.
Because a private firm looking at Texas, one of the first questions would be, does this area have an airport that will take care of my jet?
Second question will relate to the quality of life.
That'll get into parks and schools and those kinds of issues.
Then the availability of land, the availability of a skilled workforce.
All those factors are important.
So it all ties together just in a little different way and where you would start.
Sarah, planning having to take on a different form.
We've been a primarily agricultural state, primarily rural.
We're becoming more urban, suburban.
more manufacturing-oriented, does that affect our planning?
In my mind, it doesn't affect the basic steps in the planning process.
They're the science.
What it means is that the problems are different.
If you look out at needs of the population, because the fact the population is increasing rapidly,
because the population mix, which people overlook sometimes, is changing significantly.
I think we're going to identify different kinds of problems to be addressed.
But I'm a strong believer in the way to address those problems doesn't change that much.
The common sense of the planning process, whether you're dealing with Standard Oil of Indiana and their plans for the North Sea,
or the state of Texas and how it might go about an economic development strategy for the lower Rio Grande, the approach to planning is much the same, strategic planning particularly.
Same kind of steps.
Same kind of steps.
I realize you have a meeting at 3.30.
But I've got another minute if you want to raise another question.
I guess I just want to reiterate
for the purpose of the table for the book, in what direction do you think state planning should go from this point in Kansas summation?
Where should we go as a state based on what we've done in the past?
Well, let me put it in a little bit even broader context.
I think there's a very strong management responsibility in terms of the number of public dollars that we are responsible for
the effective and efficient implementation of.
There's a planning role here that is yet to evolve.
And I'm hopeful that we will continue to give attention to it.
And the piece that I think is missing, which I think is repetitive in what I've said earlier, is a strategic planning piece.
I think operational planning is done within the agencies.
I think agencies are willing to carry out public policy directives coming from the legislature.
I don't think there is a framework at this point within which the legislature makes its incremental program and budget decisions.
And I think that's a piece that's missing.
Now, as long as I have anything to do with it, I will push toward that broader, where do we want to be at some point in the future?
And what kind of steps do we take now to get there?
So one of the keys is intergovernmental cooperation among the state agencies, State Highway Department, Texas Water Resources Board, and so forth and so on.
In my mind, each of them has a lot of resources.
And within their own agencies, I think they efficiently as possible manage those resources.
I think they are denied the bigger picture.
I think each of them has a perception of where we ought to go.

I would propose to get them together and let's together agree on where the state ought to be out here, what the capacity ought to be, what the capability ought to be, what the systems ought to be, almost any aspect you can think of.
I would take them through a process in which each of us involved in this thing makes our values and our philosophies explicit and says out of that, where is it that we want to be?
I think it's a hell of a team building exercise in the first place.
I think it does a lot to bring agencies together toward a common objective.
But I think as long as we define those objectives, those goals, independent of each other, we lose something.
I think there are definitely economies here for us to sit down together and say, this is where we want to be.
Now, what part can my agency contribute to the implementation of that plan?
not how do I fight to make sure my agency gets more money in the next session.
So then it should be a function of the governor's office as?
Governor's office can facilitate that and should be leading it.
Should act as manager, as leader.
Yes.
The leadership, the focus for that kind of activity probably, that's a legitimate role for the governor.
To do the plan in the governor's office is not.
I see.
But to coordinate would be?
Yes.
No question.
Good.
That about takes care of my questions because I had planned it for about 30 minutes.
All right, all right.
Sorry, I was a little...
